pros: The student body is inspiring.  These are people who are genuinely committed to creating a more sustainable world.  A great sense of community amongst the students and a sincere interest in helping to make the school a better place.
cons: The poor management of the school is almost beyond a believable description.  From the board to the COO, leadership has consistently failed the school, the staff, the faculty and the students.  Sadly, this is a toxic place to work with over 80% of employees leaving within their first two years of employment.  Many of those who left did so without another job lined up because the environment had become that unbearable.  The school has burned through many talented staff who came to the school committed to the mission and to rolling up their sleeves in this start-up environment but who ended up broken by the chaotic, abusive, inconsistent, and under-qualified leadership.

review_title: Work here if you want a lesson in dysfunction
pros: Amazing students and faculty. Without these key components, the school would not be standing today. Unfortunately, those are the only factors that keep your initial passion for working at Presidio Graduate School alive for however long you last.
cons: Working at Presidio Graduate School took over my life. Emails, texts, and calls came around the clock from the very beginning. Work/life balance was recommended, but in actuality, looked down upon. If you did try to dedicate yourself and stay on top of every email, you'd get chastised for responding too quickly or not knowing your place. Time would be sucked up by dealing with chains of passive aggressive emails and useless staff meetings. I chose to leave the school for my own sanity.

pros: Innovative and progressive curriculum. Dedicated, passionate faculty and support staff. Fully engaged student body with high ideals and expectations. Impressive list of graduates for such a short history.
cons:
Poor, inconsistent leadership (5 presidents and 6 deans in 9 years), usually without skills or prior experience (e.g. of 11 presidents and deans, only one has held a similar position at a Higher Ed institution). Turnover is constant - only 4 of the 18 current (as of 4/4/12) employees have been there longer than a year - and not the first major turnover. 

HR is a disaster. In my experience, pay increases and promotions were based on favorites, not on performance. Further, no performance reviews were rarely, if ever done.

At the Board level, a lack of long term planning and infighting has led to several course changes that have seen the competition advance while the School loses market share.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Access and involvement with like minded professionals focused on sustainability, who are passionate about their job and the impact on the school community.
cons: Lack of leadership. The President role has been filled by an interim person for over 18 months, which has had a deep impact on staff, faculty and perhaps even curriculum.

review_title: Orwellian environment marked by bullying and deceit
pros: There are still many working to support the mission of the school, though they are in areas that have managed to avoid problem administrators.  Idealism and education retain importance in the academic program.  For now, the benefits package is good.
cons:
Faculty and staff were pressured to leave positive reviews about the school on this website; certain members were "tagged" to provide a "fresh perspective" on the school in light of the new regime, and we have been intermittently questioned about negative reviews that appeared.    

Potential employees who share the sustainable management values promoted in the school’s mission should stay away.  Upper management’s style is undemocratic and capricious, making morally and logistically untenable situations central to the work experience.  Leadership self-promote and do not treat employees with fairness or respect.  Verbal attacks from the CEO and COO occur daily; concerns are marked as performance issues or even pathologized as “outbursts.” Maintaining this dysfunction is a condition of employment.   Should a staff member exercise agency or disagree (even on the basis of professional expertise), a spiral ensues of humiliation at meetings, aggressive and fallacious censure, and restriction from the resources necessary to function on the job.  

Staff are desperately unhappy:  those who are not fired have been alienated to the point of quitting. Competence issues have been cited to staff and to people outside the school – but such accusations are unfounded and unsubstantiated.  When asked directly, the management in question could not produce a straight answer or any evidence of wrongdoing.   This pattern has repeated with old and new staff leading to almost 100% turnover within a year.
